<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPACE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/15/russia-s-antisatellite-test-added-1-500-pieces-of-trash-to-the-growing-cloud-of-space-debris?mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Russia Trash Talks in Space
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/15/russia-s-antisatellite-test-added-1-500-pieces-of-trash-to-the-growing-cloud-of-space-debris?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Kyle Mooney sitting in pile of trash." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=491 src="https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-11-15/image-fb7cb7d8821ba800f2ac3855a9a7c514e7e96788-388x284-gif/trash.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Kyle Mooney sitting in pile of trash." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-11-15/image-fb7cb7d8821ba800f2ac3855a9a7c514e7e96788-388x284-gif/trash.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The most dangerous thing in space right now isn’t aliens or cowboy Bezos—it’s more than <a href="https://apnews.com/article/space-exploration-science-business-697f5aa719331ab6e74102ebb06b52d8?utm_source=Twitter&utm_medium=AP&utm_campaign=SocialFlow" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">1,500 pieces of trash</a> from a recently obliterated Russian satellite. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">News of Russia exploding its own satellite came amid reports that seven crew members on the International Space Station (ISS) had to shelter in space’s version of a lifeboat due to debris heading their way. NASA hasn’t confirmed that the rubble the astronauts dodged was from the satellite, but ummm <img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/eyes_1f440.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> .</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What happened: </strong>In an antisatellite (ASAT) missile test Monday morning, Russia blew up its own satellite, creating a cloud of space debris that careens by the ISS every 90 minutes. The US State Department called Russia’s actions “dangerous, reckless, and irresponsible,” and NASA said the explosion will “significantly increase the risk to astronauts and cosmonauts” aboard the space station.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Some background: </strong>Antisatellite missile tests have been around since the dawn of the space race (the US launched the first one in 1959), but Russia, the US, China, and India have never used them against each other's satellites. Still, these tests are usually considered “<a href="https://www.theverge.com/2021/11/15/22782946/russia-asat-test-satellite-international-space-station-debris?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">political moves</a>” for countries to show that they <em>could</em> mess up your satellite if they wanted to.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">In space, blowing things up doesn’t make them go away</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">There are currently millions of pieces of space debris—many from past missile tests—orbiting Earth at about 22,000 mph, and they pose <a href="https://globalresilience.northeastern.edu/space-debris-poses-growing-threat-to-satellite-infrastructure/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">significant risks</a> for satellites that are critical for American military operations and a number of everyday commercial activities here on Earth, like banking and GPS.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>According to NASA, a 1-centimeter paint fleck in space can do the damage of a 550-pound object traveling 60 mph on Earth. </span></li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> As an increasing amount of economic activity relies on objects in orbit, space trash is bad for business.—<em>MM</em></p>
</div>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GEOPOLITICS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/15/president-biden-president-xi-jinping-hold-first-summit?mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Zooming With Xi
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/15/president-biden-president-xi-jinping-hold-first-summit?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="President Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/3f07b44447f1d471119ff95eee9a0963965471fb-1024x683.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Lintao Zhang/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">President Biden spoke face-to-face (well, virtually) with Chinese President Xi Jinping yesterday for the <a href="https://apnews.com/article/biden-xi-meeting-e6013378e03727b85a8f59f71fe61f4a?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">first meeting</a> between the leaders of the world’s two largest economies.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It went how most Zoom meetings go: lots of chitchat, few concrete action items. Which is disappointing for the two dozen business groups that have <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2021/11/15/investing/china-tariffs-biden/index.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">called on Biden</a> to begin reducing tariffs on China.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Why do they want that?</strong> Because of that nasty thing going around: inflation. Tariffs amount to a tax that raises prices for consumers, and the last thing the US economy needs is more inflationary pressure—prices rose at their fastest pace in 31 years in October.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The US still has tariffs dating back to the Trump administration on approximately $370 billion worth of Chinese-made goods, and Biden has signaled he’s not ready to lift them, especially since China is behind on commitments it made in a deal that took effect in February 2020.</span></li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen agreed recently that tariffs do <a href="https://www.reuters.com/business/yellen-says-reciprocal-lowering-tariffs-could-help-ease-inflation-2021-11-01/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">contribute to inflation</a>, and that both the US and China winding down tariffs in tandem “could be a desirable outcome.”—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
RETAIL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/15/casper-to-go-private-at-half-the-valuation-of-its-ipo-in-2020?mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Casper Gets Sent to the Guest Bedroom
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/15/casper-to-go-private-at-half-the-valuation-of-its-ipo-in-2020?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt='Casper sign with "S" hanging down' style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/a3e0b2038acd04e4b9398ab049e3d88bf9017585-1500x1000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Mickey McDougall; Smith Collection/Gado/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Like most of us during this time of the year, Casper is going back to bed. The mattress startup is <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/15/mattress-maker-casper-to-be-taken-private-by-pe-firm-durational-capital.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">being taken private</a> by private equity firm Durational Capital Management after an exhausting, almost-two-year stint on the NYSE.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Why exhausting? Well, the company debuted on the public markets at $14.50/share in February 2020. Last Friday, it closed at a paltry $3.55.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The air mattress arc</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Founded in 2014, Casper was a pioneer of the direct-to-consumer model—and through its convenient “bed-in-a-box” distribution strategy and incessant advertising, it worked its way up to a $1.1 billion valuation, nabbing investments from celebs like Nas and Ashton Kutcher.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But somewhere along the way of trying to become the “Nike of sleep,” it <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/retail/stories/2020/02/07/casper-bed-box-pioneer-makes-lackluster-stock-exchange-debut?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">tripped</a> on a shoelace. Casper went public at just a $575 million valuation and continued to lose money, even as it opened retail stores and inked partnerships with Target and Mattress Warehouse. Not even a <a href="https://www.fastcompany.com/90203658/i-tried-to-fall-sleep-in-the-dreamery-caspers-new-nap-bar?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">nap bar</a> in Manhattan could help distinguish it from the competition. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>Casper’s departure from the stock exchange comes right after a flood of D2C superstars, such as Warby Parker and Allbirds, made their public debuts.—<em>MM</em></p>
</div>

<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/15/key-performance-indicators-november-16?mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Key Performance Indicators
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>Beef—it’s what’s for dinner if you want to eat ramen for the rest of the week. Meat giant Tyson Foods said its average beef prices rose by <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/tysons-meat-production-falls-amid-labor-shortages-11636983508?mod=hp_lead_pos2" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">nearly one-third</a> over last year. Meanwhile, pork prices jumped 38% and chicken ~19%. “The inflation we incur needs to be passed on,” Tyson’s CFO said.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>“The only thing worse than being copied by Twitter and Facebook is not being copied by Twitter and Facebook.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Substack CEO Chris Best <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/ee71edee-eae7-46e2-99e1-61af23ce56e2?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">told the FT</a> he feels vindicated that the big social media platforms have launched their own newsletter products to rival his. Four years after its launch, Substack now has 1 million paying subscribers, the company announced yesterday.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Read: </strong>How <em>Succession </em>makes wealth look miserable. (<a href="https://www.theringer.com/succession/2021/11/11/22775852/succession-set-design-costumes-clothes-cinematography?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">The Ringer</a>)</p>
</div>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
REAL ESTATE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/15/the-most-expensive-us-zip-codes-got-significantly-pricier-this-year?mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Zip Codes of the Rich & Famous
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/15/the-most-expensive-us-zip-codes-got-significantly-pricier-this-year?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="A map of the US labeling the top 10 most expensive zip codes in the US" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/e7004b1b4b051ddb9b383e0b4676090b9fe2dd67-3592x2318.png?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>PropertyShark</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Great news for heirs about to be bequeathed the estate of a wealthy, recently deceased relative: The most expensive zip codes in the US got even pricier this year.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A new report from real estate data company <a href="https://www.propertyshark.com/Real-Estate-Reports/most-expensive-zip-codes-in-the-us?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew#Ranking_the_Priciest_US_Zip_Codes_by_Closed_Home_Sales" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Property Shark</a> found that for the first time, every one of the 10 most expensive zip codes in the US had a median home sales price of at least $4 million. And the number of zip codes with median sale prices of $3+ million doubled from last year, to 30.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The top 10:</strong></p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>94207: Atherton, CA (home to Steph Curry)</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>02199: Boston, MA</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>11962: Sagaponack, NY</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>94957: Ross, CA</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>33109: Miami Beach, FL</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>90210: Beverly Hills, CA</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>93108: Santa Barbara, CA</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>90402: Santa Monica, CA</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>94022: Los Altos, CA</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>98039: Medina, WA</span></li>
</ol>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The 1% must be very neighborly: 92 of the 127 most expensive zip codes registered home-price gains this year, and 23 of those had price increases of over 25%.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Pour one out for:</strong> NYC’s Upper West Side, one of only 12 zip codes on the leaderboard to register a decrease in home sale prices this year, falling 39%. Must be those rowdy philharmonic concerts at Lincoln Center.—<em>MK</em></p>
</div>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Brew Mini: </strong><em>Sopranos, </em>Katy Perry, elite colleges...this crossword has it all. <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/15/brew-mini-pancetta?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Solve it here</a>.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Useless Playing Card Trivia </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">How well do you know your playing cards? Give these five questions a shuffle. </p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>This is the only King without a mustache.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Which is the only Queen that faces to the right?</span></li>

<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>What does the number 8.0658175e+67 represent?</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>What is unique about the Jack of Clubs?</span></li>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-bottom:15px;line-height:22px;">

src=\"https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-11-15/image-fb7cb7d8821ba800f2ac3855a9a7c514e7e96788-388x284-gif/trash.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c!--\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe most dangerous thing in space right now isn’t aliens or cowboy Bezos—it’s more than \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/space-exploration-science-business-697f5aa719331ab6e74102ebb06b52d8?utm_source=Twitter\u0026utm_medium=AP\u0026utm_campaign=SocialFlow\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e1,500 pieces of trash\u003c/a\u003e from a recently obliterated Russian satellite. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNews of Russia exploding its own satellite came amid reports that seven crew members on the International Space Station (ISS) had to shelter in space’s version of a lifeboat due to debris heading their way. NASA hasn’t confirmed that the rubble the astronauts dodged was from the satellite, but ummm \u003cimg src=\"https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/eyes_1f440.png\" width=\"18\" style=\"max-width:18px\" alt=\"\"\u003e .\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat happened: \u003c/strong\u003eIn an antisatellite (ASAT) missile test Monday morning, Russia blew up its own satellite, creating a cloud of space debris that careens by the ISS every 90 minutes. The US State Department called Russia’s actions “dangerous, reckless, and irresponsible,” and NASA said the explosion will “significantly increase the risk to astronauts and cosmonauts” aboard the space station.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSome background: \u003c/strong\u003eAntisatellite missile tests have been around since the dawn of the space race (the US launched the first one in 1959), but Russia, the US, China, and India have never used them against each other's satellites. Still, these tests are usually considered “\u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2021/11/15/22782946/russia-asat-test-satellite-international-space-station-debris?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epolitical moves\u003c/a\u003e” for countries to show that they \u003cem\u003ecould\u003c/em\u003e mess up your satellite if they wanted to.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eIn space, blowing things up doesn’t make them go away\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThere are currently millions of pieces of space debris—many from past missile tests—orbiting Earth at about 22,000 mph, and they pose \u003ca href=\"https://globalresilience.northeastern.edu/space-debris-poses-growing-threat-to-satellite-infrastructure/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esignificant risks\u003c/a\u003e for satellites that are critical for American military operations and a number of everyday commercial activities here on Earth, like banking and GPS.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAccording to NASA, a 1-centimeter paint fleck in space can do the damage of a 550-pound object traveling 60 mph on Earth. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line:\u003c/strong\u003e As an increasing amount of economic activity relies on objects in orbit, space trash is bad for business.—\u003cem\u003eMM\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePresident Biden spoke face-to-face (well, virtually) with Chinese President Xi Jinping yesterday for the \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/biden-xi-meeting-e6013378e03727b85a8f59f71fe61f4a?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efirst meeting\u003c/a\u003e between the leaders of the world’s two largest economies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt went how most Zoom meetings go: lots of chitchat, few concrete action items. Which is disappointing for the two dozen business groups that have \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2021/11/15/investing/china-tariffs-biden/index.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecalled on Biden\u003c/a\u003e to begin reducing tariffs on China.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhy do they want that?\u003c/strong\u003e Because of that nasty thing going around: inflation. Tariffs amount to a tax that raises prices for consumers, and the last thing the US economy needs is more inflationary pressure—prices rose at their fastest pace in 31 years in October.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe US still has tariffs dating back to the Trump administration on approximately $370 billion worth of Chinese-made goods, and Biden has signaled he’s not ready to lift them, especially since China is behind on commitments it made in a deal that took effect in February 2020.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen agreed recently that tariffs do \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/business/yellen-says-reciprocal-lowering-tariffs-could-help-ease-inflation-2021-11-01/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003econtribute to inflation\u003c/a\u003e, and that both the US and China winding down tariffs in tandem “could be a desirable outcome.”—\u003cem\u003eNF\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" the year, Casper is going back to bed. The mattress startup is \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/15/mattress-maker-casper-to-be-taken-private-by-pe-firm-durational-capital.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebeing taken private\u003c/a\u003e by private equity firm Durational Capital Management after an exhausting, almost-two-year stint on the NYSE.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhy exhausting? Well, the company debuted on the public markets at $14.50/share in February 2020. Last Friday, it closed at a paltry $3.55.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe air mattress arc\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFounded in 2014, Casper was a pioneer of the direct-to-consumer model—and through its convenient “bed-in-a-box” distribution strategy and incessant advertising, it worked its way up to a $1.1 billion valuation, nabbing investments from celebs like Nas and Ashton Kutcher.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut somewhere along the way of trying to become the “Nike of sleep,” it \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/retail/stories/2020/02/07/casper-bed-box-pioneer-makes-lackluster-stock-exchange-debut?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etripped\u003c/a\u003e on a shoelace. Casper went public at just a $575 million valuation and continued to lose money, even as it opened retail stores and inked partnerships with Target and Mattress Warehouse. Not even a \u003ca href=\"https://www.fastcompany.com/90203658/i-tried-to-fall-sleep-in-the-dreamery-caspers-new-nap-bar?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enap bar\u003c/a\u003e in Manhattan could help distinguish it from the competition. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eCasper’s departure from the stock exchange comes right after a flood of D2C superstars, such as Warby Parker and Allbirds, made their public debuts.—\u003cem\u003eMM\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL
